Award.AwardTitle: CDS&E/Collaborative Research: Fundamental Investigation of Zinc-Coating of Advanced High Strength Steels Directed by Multiscale Modeling and Experiments

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
New-generation advanced high strength steels need to be coated with a thin layer of zinc that provides corrosion protection to the substrate. Thus, zinc coating is a critical component that enables steels to maintain structural integrity for prolonged service times. Prediction and control of the coating process requires better understanding of interfacial reactions between zinc and steel substrate, which are very complex. This Computational and Data-Enabled Science and Engineering (CDS&E) collaborative research award supports fundamental research that combines cutting-edge experimental techniques and multi-scale computer simulations to study the interfacial microstructures that develop during coating. The outcomes of this research will provide guidelines for improved coating of advanced high strength steel sheets which enable production of lighter and safer vehicles, and ultimately contribute to reducing emissions of green-house gases. This project also provides an opportunity to educate engineering students with cross-discipline computational and experimental skills.

The zinc-steel interfacial structures determine the success or failure of forming, welding, and corrosion protection capabilities of advanced high strength steels. There is a lack of fundamental knowledge regarding the process-microstructure-property relationships in zinc-coated steels produced by galvanizing and galvannealing, due to the fact that complex metallurgical reactions occur in a region less than 100 nanometers. The research team will utilize focused ion beam to prepare specimens for transmission electron microscopy analyses to resolve complicated, fine-scale interfacial microstructures and to reveal the chemistry of the interfacial entities. The data will be used to calibrate and validate cross-length scale models, spanning from the electronic to mesoscale. Density functional theory calculations will be performed to determine structures and properties of oxides and intermetallics. The obtained data will be used to develop multicomponent interatomic potentials based on the modified embedded-atom method. These potentials will be employed in large-scale atomistic simulations to determine energetics data for the formation of oxides and intermetallics. The experimental and atomistic modeling data will be fed to unprecedented multicomponent, multi-phase field models to simulate formation and evolution of microstructures of internal/external oxidation, inhibition layer, and intermetallics. The iterations between experiments and models will provide a unique approach to facilitate the discovery of new coating processes for advanced high strength steels.

Institution.Name: Colorado School of Mines
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: TRUSTEES OF THE COLORADO SCHOOL OF MINES

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Computational and Data-Enabled Science and Engineering (CDS&E) collaborative research award supported fundamental research to study the thermomechanical and physical properties of advanced high strength steels and their coating process.  New-generation advanced high strength steels need particular nano and microstructures and a thin layer of zinc coating that provides corrosion protection. The coating is a critical component that enables steels to maintain structural integrity for prolonged service times. Prediction and control of the coating process requires better understanding of nano and microstructures of steels, the oxidation of steels during the coating process, and the interfacial reactions between zinc and the steel substrate. In this project, a new nanoscale computational framework was developed for steels enabling understanding fundamental mechanisms controlling phase formation and properties of steels. At the microscale, a quantitative computational model was created for predicting the formation and evolution of oxides and the resulting local stresses and strains in high temperature oxidation of steels. The results of the multiscale computational modeling provided strategies for designing the nano and microstructures of steels for improving their properties and oxidation resistance, and laid out the foundation for future investigation of the coating process of steels.

The outcomes of this project can contribute in production of high-strength lightweight steels which have several important applications, including in making of cars and aerospace vehicles. Minimizing the defect formations in manufacturing and increasing the strength of these materials enables production of light-weight high-strength materials for making vehicles with high fuel efficiency and greater safety. This may also significantly contribute in lowering the greenhouse-gas emissions and enabling production of environment-friendly vehicles. This project also provided opportunities to educate engineering students, at both undergraduate and graduate levels, with the cross-discipline computational and experimental skills.


Last Modified: 12/31/2020
Modified by: Mohsen Asle Zaeem

At the microscale, a quantitative computational model was created for predicting the formation and evolution of oxides and the resulting local stresses and strains in high temperature oxidation of steels. The outcomes of this project can contribute in production of high-strength lightweight steels which have several important applications, including in making of cars and aerospace vehicles. Minimizing the defect formations in manufacturing and increasing the strength of these materials enables production of light-weight high-strength materials for making vehicles with high fuel efficiency and greater safety. This project also provided opportunities to educate engineering students, at both undergraduate and graduate levels, with the cross-discipline computational and experimental skills.
